name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
To all those struggling to feed their babies, my message to you is ‚ÄúI hear you.‚Äù

Congress hears you and we are taking swift action to make sure this never happens again.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Since the onset of the baby formula shortage, I have been steadfast in my commitment to finding a solution. My bipartisan, Access to Baby Formula Act will ensure flexibility so we can help WIC participants access formula from other companies https://t.co/rJNN5aXWym

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: This crisis was caused by the simultaneous manufacturing recall at Abbott Nutrition and ongoing pandemic related supply chain issues. WIC families are impacted the hardest as Abbott formula serves 89% of all infants participating in WIC.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Among the most vulnerable, are mothers and babies enrolled in the WIC program who use formula at roughly double the rate of non-participating families ‚Äì disproportionally impacting communities and families with the highest need.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Families lucky enough to find formula in their local stores, the prices they are paying have increased dramatically, in some cases rising 18% over the past year.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
In #CT05 parents have joined FB groups to track where they can find formula. They‚Äôre waiting in lines outside of stores, buying sample packs on the streets, even resorting to the dangerous practice of watering down their formula just to stretch their supply. 

They are desperate.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Now mothers across our country are feeling the desperation, guilt, and anxiety of not being able to adequately feed their babies during the most critical time in their development.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: üßµWe are in the midst of a national emergency, where families are panicking as they work to prevent their babies from going hungry. Since April, around 40% of formula products were out of stock in 7 states ‚Äì including my home state of Connecticut.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Thank you @JusticeKetanji 
Today was a good day for America. 
Tonight I am filled with joy!

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Today‚Äôs confirmation means so much to so many and so much to me! You will never know what it means to not be represented until you belong to a group that is not represented. 
We have so much much work to do to ensure our institutions are representative &  inclusive of all.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: I never really thought about what it means to not have a Black woman on the Supreme Court until I thought about what it means to not have a Black woman on the Supreme Court.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: My body trembled, my checks got hot and my eyes filled with tears as I felt the pains of this eerily familiar journey playing out in the chamber.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
I listened, I looked, I watched but what I never expected is what I felt‚Ä¶. 
An overwhelming sense of pride, sadness, relief, a swell of emotions in the pit of my stomach as I witnessed history unfolding before my eyes.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: I watched the Vice President preside over the chamber in a compulsory fashion trying to fulfill her duty in an unbiased way.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: I looked at staffers and interns trying to curb their enthusiasm, but visibly struck by the magnitude of what they were witnessing.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: I held on to the sound of every Senator who enthusiastically voted aye and tried to keep a mental tally. I looked up in the galley at a collection of faces I had never seen before holding hands and clearly praying.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
I listened as Senators accused her of violating the constitution by defending criminals. (which is the most basic of our constitutionally protected rights) 
I listened to Senators comment on how qualified she was before voting NO.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Please forgive my late post- but reflection is part of a teacher‚Äôs DNA.

Today, I sat in the Senate chamber while the confirmation vote for Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson was taken. https://t.co/NQR0psEC94

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Myth #5: SNAP completely covers the costs of food for recipients

Fact: SNAP was built to supplement household food costs, not completely cover them. In fact, prior to the Thrifty Food Plan update, SNAP did not cover the cost of a low-income meal in 96% of U.S. counties. https://t.co/Ga1kooiQAA

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Myth #4: SNAP disincentivizes work

Fact: A majority of SNAP recipients who can work, do work. More than 80% of SNAP households work in the year before or the year after receiving SNAP. https://t.co/v8XoClNqw5

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Myth #3: SNAP is rife with fraud

Fact: SNAP fraud is exceedingly rare. According to the Congressional Research Service, less than .01% of 
benefits have been mistakenly issued due to recipient fraud. https://t.co/02FnPEkkPJ

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Myth #2: Charities can replace the help SNAP provides

Fact: While food banks provide meals for food-insecure communities, SNAP is far more wide-reaching and efficient. SNAP delivers nine times more food to people than all the food banks in the country. https://t.co/VV6rhAqPjl

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Myth #1: SNAP drains the economy

Fact: For every dollar utilized by a SNAP recipient, $1.79 is infused into their local economy. Additionally, SNAP lowers healthcare costs by nearly $1,400 per person. https://t.co/mIH2eluwJ1

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: On October 1st, SNAP benefits will increase by 21% permanently. I know there are many misconceptions about the program. Here are five common myths and facts about SNAP benefits you should know. https://t.co/AQAqZ2n1vi

tweet_text:

Stop tossing families off the b‚Ä¶

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - "This is not a charity. This is our moral obligation." - @RepMcGovern "To be poor in this country is a full time job."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: . @RepMcGovern added "I'm grateful that in the American Rescue Plan we upped it by 15% but talk to food banks and they'll tell you that people are still coming to food banks midway through the month because their benefits have run out."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepMcGovern continued " My criticism to SNAP is that the benefit is too small. On average it is $1.40 /person/meal. My Dunkin Donuts coffee this morning cost me more than that."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepMcGovern "SNAP is the most important anti-hunger program that we have. Charity can't do it alone, and by the way, SNAP is not charity."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: "If they could get access to somebody else making it for them, and still have that self-pride of getting a meal, they will not have to go to junk-food." - #TheFutureofSNAP

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP witness Ms. Davis continued "There are people who don't have a stove. They're not very skilled at cooking or know much about it..."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
#TheFutureofSNAP - @RepAlLawsonJr  asks about the impact of inadequate support from SNAP to meet the needs of families lacking hot food access, especially during natural disasters such as hurricanes.

Witness Ms. Davis shared "It is good to have access to hot meals."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @Kilili_Sablan spoke on bringing SNAP benefits to the Northern Mariana Islands. "I had conversations with those who are home bound & some of them lost their qualification for food assistance because their income is $2 higher than the threshold.‚Äù

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP "It has to be collaboratively co-designed with community partners, so that we are utilizing all of the assets and existing resources within communities most productively and we are reaching families deepest in need." - @RBoyntonJarrett

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepKatCammack asked @RBoyntonJarrett how we may be able to look at ways to promote healthy food, support our [food] producers, and meet the needs of families and individuals struggling.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @RepJimmyPanetta added that when he volunteered at food banks, he saw the growing lines. "What I've realized and what I believe is, we couldn't food bank our way out of the pandemic and we cannot food bank our way out of hunger."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepJimmyPanetta "Nearly 9% of my constituents relied on SNAP, 1/4 children were food insecure, & by the end of last year, household food insecurity spiked to above 35% in certain parts of my district."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepAnnieKuster "Food insecurity is plaguing my state, and while I appreciate the role of the churches, I certainly believe that the government has an important role to this as well, to ensure equity..."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
#TheFutureofSNAP - "We need to work much more collaboratively to build a more resilient food system, and SNAP is a big piece of that. Also engaging parents and members of the community..." @RBoyntonJarrett 
Chronic food insecurity is traumatic & an experience you will not forget.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP - @RepCarbajal "I personally know how critical food assistance can be for families. When I was young, these programs actually helped reduce the financial barriers for my parents, who were struggling to get by making minimum wage, working as farm workers."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
#TheFutureofSNAP - @RepAdams shared that she was once a SNAP recipient and understands the experience many are encountering.

"Working hard is not enough, if you don't make enough."

name: Jahana Hayes
Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Wilson continued to express her concern for the well-being of her children. Wilson is working diligently on recovering from job loss and decrease in work due to the pandemic. She hopes that she never has to experience this again. #TheFutureofSNAP

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: "Sometimes we [parents] set aside all of our pride to ensure our kids don't experience the effects of poverty."

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: "I am doing my very best with government assistance to get them the very best they need." Before the pandemic, she did not need government assistance.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
#TheFutureofSNAP SNAP recipient & witness Ms. Wilson, a mother a mother of 2, shared candidly about her children and her experience with SNAP.

"Government assistance is not a way of life," said Wilson.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP "We know that when children lack basic access to these basic necessities, even for brief periods of time, their health is jeopardized...They are more likely to be in poor health, hospitalized, & at risk for developmental delays." Dr.@RBoyntonJarrett

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: #TheFutureofSNAP witness Mr. Whitford, executive director of the Watered Gardens Ministries shared his experience those without a home. He reflects on the SNAP legislation over last two decades that impacted many around the country who were unsure of what was next.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Davis was able to receive the P-EBT card and utilized the food pantry. She stayed focused and thanks her support system for standing by her.  She is now a graduate of Montgomery County Community College and plan to launch her own restaurant to help others. 

#TheFutureofSNAP

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Davis started a support group,"Back on Track," with other single mothers in community college who were sharing similar experiences as her. The group was a success with supporting others. 

COVID impacted her tremendously. She was denied unemployment.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: SNAP recipient & witness today, Odessa Davis shares "I had to put my pride to the side and get the assistance I needed." SNAP helped her with her bills due to minimum wage pay, and her son who was able to stay nourished while at school allowing him to stay focused.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
On this Subcommittee, we have an opportunity to ensure that these supports are strengthened for Americans in each of our districts. I am excited about this work and look forward to continuing to deliver for the American people. 
https://t.co/nXUaiduWNd

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: They are a critical support which ensures that hunger is not another obstacle in the way of Americans striving for stability.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: That memory of stress, and the threat of hunger, is a reality that I take into this work as Chairwoman of this Subcommittee. My lived experience has shown me that SNAP, and other safety net programs, are not just hand-outs for people unwilling to work toward self-sufficiency.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: As a young mother, I worked two jobs and attended school. But I still qualified for benefits. SNAP allowed me to put food in my children‚Äôs mouths while I worked by way to economic stability.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: While anecdotally there may be such instances ‚Äì these programs work and they are lifesavers. I know this because they saved my life.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: That SNAP benefits discourage work; that emergency allotments and a 15% increase in benefits are just too expensive; that there is fraud within the SNAP program requiring updated quality control measures.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: During this hearing, I am sure we may also hear some concerns regarding the SNAP program....

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Hunger effects our friends and neighbors, the elderly, the disabled, single mothers, working parents, and people of all ages, races and beliefs.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Today‚Äôs testimony will show that fear of hunger is not an economic motivator, but an obstacle to success, and threat to public health. And that hunger does not discriminate. It exists in every one of our districts.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: This testimony will illustrate what I know to be true from first-hand experience: that SNAP is a hand-up, not a hand-out, for Americans striving to achieve self-sufficiency.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: As we will hear from our panel of witnesses today, SNAP during COVID has been crucial for those suddenly without an income, as well as parents forced to choose between a job and caring for their children in remote school.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: ‚Äìand also to use those lessons as a roadmap for closing the glaring gaps in policy which left so many Americans food insecure in the first place.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: The title of today‚Äôs hearing is ‚ÄúThe Future of SNAP: Moving Past the Pandemic.‚Äù The purpose of this hearing is to recount the lessons we have learned about food security and nutrition access during the COVID-19 crisis...

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC I am looking forward to more chats in the future. It was great to discuss the strides we have made in bridging the #DigitalDivide, closing the #HomeworkGap, and the work that still needs to be done to improve access to education for all. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @FCC The pandemic highlighted and exacerbated the issues we were already aware of with the #DigitalDivide. Many households do not have access to broadband and that leaves them behind in school, jobs, and everyday life. We need connections now more than ever. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC So much of school today requires the internet. We risk widening the achievement gap if we do not fix this soon. We need to make sure the internet is affordable and accessible for everyone. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC The #homeworkgap needs attention. Millions of kids across this country‚Äîin rural and urban and everywhere in between‚Äîcan not do their homework or participate in class during the #COVID19 pandemic because they cannot get online. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC This is an issue that is close to my heart. It is something that I have seen firsthand - students struggling through lack of internet access in Waterbury, Connecticut. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC But now, we need to expand #ERate beyond schools and into the homes of students as so many kids are learning remotely during this pandemic. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC #ERate and being able to use the internet to expand my students‚Äô horizons was critical. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @FCC This bill created a Universal Service Fund to support access by those in rural areas, as well as low-income Americans. It demonstrated that broadband connectivity must reach all Americans, regardless of who they are or where they live. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @FCC The Telecom Act started us down the path of ever-expanding network connectivity. It recognized the importance of digital access and equity ‚Äì something we are still working on today. And it codified the idea that the internet should be affordable for all.  #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC As a career educator, I am especially interested in how this law brought the internet into schools and libraries. How it has changed how teachers teach and students learn. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: @JRosenworcelFCC @FCC Thanks @FCC & Acting Chairwoman @JRosenworcelFCC for chatting today. It is always a privilege to take a break from my day job in Congress and return to what I love best - teaching. #TelecomActChat

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: These measures protect both the members of our community and the police who serve them.‚Äù

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: The legislation leverages access to existing federal funding by conditioning it upon increased training, banning practices like chokeholds and no-knock warrants, limiting use of force, and requiring public reporting when force is used.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: The Justice in Policing Act of 2020 does not in any way defund the police. It holds police accountable by giving American citizens recourse if they believe there has been a violation.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text: Simultaneously, I support addressing the underlying, structural inequalities which expose communities to police violence.

name: Jahana Hayes
tweet_text:
Here is my full statement (not included) which makes my position clear
‚ÄúI do not support defunding the police. I support implementation of greater training, accountability, and transparency to ensure that police forces sworn to protect our communities have the needed resources‚Äù https://t.co/0WoVyhSpLf
